column1: The CQA includes using required vale tools to identify and fix asciidoc content so that it can be migrated.  Complete the following steps:
1. Time saver! Run the Asciidoc Content Type Editor and fix any errors.
Fixing content type issues before running the asciidoctor-data-vale tool fixes a lot of potential errors.
2. Run the Vale asciidoctor-dita-vale tool check and address any errors and warnings. (See row 37)
See the ToolX migration tool page for more information.
Tip: Use the Vale CLI to scan many files at once. Use the Vale VS Code extension to find the issues in the files.
3. Complete the rest of the items (rows 33 and following) on the Pre-migration tab.
4. Continue to use the Vale VS Code extension to lint your content as you continue to work before migration so that you don't add migration issues.
Content passes this Vale asciidoctor-dita-vale tool check with no errors or warnings

column1: Modules and assemblies start with a clear short description. A short description:   - Describes why the user should read the content - Uses concise language that will be used as a link preview or for summaries in search results - Includes keywords that users are likey to search on for SEO and AI  - Must not include self referential language ("This document describes...")
column8: See the following doc about shortdesc in DITA:  https://docs.oasis-open.org/dita/dita/v1.3/errata02/os/complete/part3-all-inclusive/langRef/base/shortdesc.html

column1: In asciidoc, short descriptions must be: - be a single paragraph between 50 and 300 characters  - Introduced with [role="_abstract"]  - Include a blank line between the level 0 (=) title and the short description in asciidoc
column8: Note: See Rewrite for Impact: DITA short descriptions
